The Signal

What COVID-19 is doing to Brazil

The poorest Brazilians are coming up with grassroots answers to COVID-19, even as the spread of the virus accelerates. So how is the pandemic changing their country?

World

  1. 'Major incident' declared as thousands flock to UK beach despite pandemic

    Local authorities in the popular beachside town of Bournemouth urge people to leave the town after it became "stretched to the absolute hilt" during a second day of heatwave-like conditions as temperatures hit 33C.

  2. Chinese structures appear near border disputed with India

    There had been talk of tensions cooling on the China, India border but one week after 20 Indian troops were killed in fighting new satellite images show structures being built on the Chinese side, leaving India to verbally hit out.

  3. NASA simulation shows what sunsets might look like on other worlds

    Animated videos of computer simulated sunsets show what the sky might look like if you were looking up through a super-wide camera lens from Venus, Mars, Uranus or Titan.

  4. Marathon vote on extending Vladimir Putin's rule in Russia begins

    Russians will begin casting their ballots in a seven-day vote on sweeping reforms that could see President Vladimir Putin stay in the Kremlin until 2036, an exercise that critics call a constitutional coup.

Asia Pacific

  1. How a holiday in Fiji might look like under the proposed 'Bula Bubble'

    Fiji's decimated tourism industry is hoping the latest proposal to establish a travel bubble in the region will help see the return of much-needed Australian visitors to the Pacific island nation.

  2. New footage shows baby elephants getting their 'spirits broken' to work in Thai tourism trade

    The footage shows elephants chained up and trained to perform tricks, like walking on their hind legs, spinning a hula hoop with their trunks or painting on a canvas.

  3. Is there even such a thing as a 'second wave'?

    What actually constitutes a second wave of coronavirus infections, and if South Korea is experiencing one now, which countries are likely to to be next?

  4. Stargazers in Asia and Middle East observe rare 'ring of fire'

    A shimmering ring of light flashed into view on Sunday in parts of the eastern hemisphere as the moon drifted across the face of the sun in a rare eclipse.

Business

  1. Analysis: Alan Joyce has just popped the bubble of the V-shaped recovery. Here's why

    The Qantas job cuts send a stark message to anyone who thought the bounce-back from coronavirus was going to be swift and strong. Alan Joyce just told them they're dreaming.

  2. Qantas to cut 6,000 jobs, grounds most international flights until July 2021

    Qantas will cut at least 6,000 jobs across all parts of the business as part of its long-term response to the coronavirus pandemic and will not resume substantial international travel until July 2021.

  3. Fire, ice and coronavirus mark tough year for Alpine regions

    Snowfields celebrate the start of the ski season, but Alpine areas are counting a hefty cost from summer bushfires and coronavirus restrictions.

  4. 'I want my old life back': Families forced to make big changes due to coronavirus

    Pansy Leung and her husband both worked as cabin crew for Virgin until they were stood down in March. She now works on a supermarket checkout and packs boxes for a meal-delivery company.

Sport

  1. 'I will never forget this moment': Australia and New Zealand will host 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup

    The best female soccer players the world has to offer will be making the trip down under in 2023 as Australia and New Zealand win the right to host the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup.

  2. Bulldogs beat Swans as AFL remembers John Kennedy Sr

    An undermanned Bulldogs outfit posts a 28-point win over Sydney at the SCG, as both sides pay tribute to an AFL Legend.

  3. Nathan Cleary goes from hospital to Penrith hero in win over Rabbitohs

    The Penrith half-back, laid low by an infection, helps guide the Panthers to a 20-12 win over South Sydney, moving them to the top of the ladder.

  4. What you need to know about Australia-New Zealand's winning women's World Cup bid

    Australia found out on Friday morning it will be hosting the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup with New Zealand. Check out all you need to know about the bid that has made history.

Arts & Culture

  1. ABC budget cuts to affect department behind You Can't Ask That, Revelation, War on Waste

    The ABC will reduce funding to factual programs and broadcast fewer hours of original television as part of a new plan to meet budget cuts.

  2. Arts rescue package unveiled as sector calls for coronavirus lifeline

    Australia's arts sector will get access to $250 million worth of grants and loans under a COVID-19 recovery package unveiled by the Federal Government.

  3. Australian musical theatre star Michael Falzon dies

    Michael Falzon, the musical theatre star who played the lead role in the original production of We Will Rock You, dies aged 48.

  4. National Gallery confirms jobs will be cut as it faces reported $3.6 million shortfall

    Facing budgetary pressures and low visitor numbers due to bushfire smoke and coronavirus, the National Gallery of Australia says it will have to "modernise" and confirms staff will be made redundant.

Good News

  1. Youngest-ever World Cup footballer says a women's Australia-New Zealand World Cup will uncover next crop of Matildas

    Caitlin Foord, the youngest-ever World Cup footballer says a women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand will uncover the next crop of Matildas.

  2. 'I knew I'd get somewhere in life': Jobs program gets results for youngsters in WA

    A tailored approach to job training is helping young Indigenous girls find their confidence and develop the skills they need to enter the workforce.

  3. Qantas Founders Museum lights up to lure tourists back to outback

    The historic aircraft museum is celebrating 100 years of Qantas with a high-tech lightshow in outback Queensland, with high hopes the $3 million display will attract tourists to the region.

  4. 'Whopping' koala rescued from army base befriends the captain who saved him

    A very large koala rescued near Oakey has been released back into the wild after being found suffering from a condition that could have sent him blind.

Health

  1. Do I really need to get my family tested every time we have a runny nose this winter?

    So your child has a runny nose for the third time this month and you're exhausted by just the thought of getting the whole family tested and going into isolation again. Is it excessive to get tested for COVID-19 at every cough or sneeze? Or more important than ever?

  2. Could there be a link between baldness and coronavirus?

    Two small studies published recently suggested bald men were over-represented in those in hospital with COVID-19. While this may sound strange, science does offer a plausible explanation, writes Jenny Graves.

  3. Picnics, cinema and carpooling: Experts warn against one of these three things

    Restrictions on the ways we socialise have been significantly wound back, but that doesn't mean the coronavirus pandemic is over. We asked the experts whether you should go to that party, share that bowl of chips or go in for that hug.

  4. Coronavirus fight enters 'phase 5', but experts look ahead to what comes next

    With cases on the rise again in Victoria, COVID-19 has delivered a sharp lesson in vigilance. But thoughts are already turning to the future, as health experts turn their focus to what comes next.

Rural

  1. Bayer to settle Roundup cancer cases with $15.9b payout

    Global pharmaceutical giant Bayer will spend up to $US10.9 billion ($15.87b) to settle thousands of lawsuits alleging the company's weedkiller, Roundup, causes cancer.

  2. Government backs agricultural shows with $36m lifeline after cancellations this year

    The Australian Government puts in an extra $36 million to support agricultural show societies after many cancelled their 2020 events.

  3. Government backs agricultural shows with $36m lifeline after cancellations this year

    The Australian Government puts in an extra $36 million to support agricultural show societies after many cancelled their 2020 events.

  4. Replica of Mad Max compound built for film's 40th anniversary

    The collection of Mad Max monuments at Silverton will soon boast a new exhibition — a replica of the second film's iconic compound.
